Description:
"Musica Dolente" is dedicated to the innocent victims of the tragic events of Septemer 11, 2001. Aivars KalÄ“js: "The world has come close. What we give against violence that does not want to intermit on the earth? Love, true fraternal love."

Aivars KalÄ“js - "Musica Dolente" for symphony orchestra.

The record is included in CD "Latvian Symponic Music. 21st Century." Awarded in the International competition "Sinfonia Baltica" (2004)

Ko likt pretÄ« varmÄcÄ«bai, kura negrib rimties zemes virsÅ«? MÄ«lestÄ«bu, Ä«stu brÄÄ¼u mÄ«lestÄ«bu."

Aivars KalÄ“js is a Latvian composer, organist and pianist. Studied with Nikolajs VanadziÅ†Å¡, Ä€dolfs Skulte and LÅ«cija GarÅ«ta.
He has written about 100 opuses of symphonic, organ, piano, chamber and choir music. His works have been played in concerts around the world, published in editions such as BÃ¤renreiter, Edition Peters and have won several composition awards, e.g. symphonic work "De Profundis''. His works are included in many CD's of the great musicians and collectives such as Iveta Apkalna and Latvian National Symphony Orchestra.
KalÄ“js has given concerts in almost all of the European countries, the USA, Canada, Japan and has participated in dozens of international organ festivals. Six solo CDs and participation in many CD recordings. He has performed with countless national symphony orchestras and collectives such as Kremerata Baltica and State Choir Latvija, as well as collaborations with many great musicians such as conductors Andris Nelsons and Pierre Cao, violinist Gidon Kremer, soprano Inessa Galante, French horn player ArvÄ«ds KliÅ¡Äns, violist Maxim Novikov and cellist Alexander Kniazew.

Title: Andris Nelsons, Olivier Latry, BSO & Gewandhausorchester â€“ Strauss: Festliches PrÃ¤ludium, Op. 61
Description:
As part of the multidimensional artistic alliance established between his two world-class orchestras, visionary conductor Andris Nelsons has recorded all the major orchestral works of Richard Strauss with the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Leipzig Gewandhausorchester. The BSO is joined by legendary cellist Yo-Yo Ma in Don Quixote, while star pianist Yuja Wang appears with the Leipzig players in Burleske. The two orchestras join forces on the recording of the Festliches PrÃ¤ludium for large orchestra and organ, made with organist Olivier Latry in Symphony Hall in November 2019 while the Gewandhausorchester was on tour in Boston. 

â€œThis joint Strauss project is very dear to my heart,â€ says Andris Nelsons. â€œThroughout the past few years, it has been a source  of hope and comfort. The music of Richard Strauss means so much to me in its great emotional scope, its story-telling powers and significant influence on the development of classical music. I am deeply grateful to have the opportunity to share it with our music communities in Boston and Leipzig and throughout the world. The collaborative efforts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Gewandhausorchester are a dream come true for me, and I will be forever thankful to my dear colleagues at both orchestras and at Deutsche Grammophon for all they have done to achieve this unique project. Our hope is that these recordings will bring much joy and inspiration.â€   


Andris Nelsons, Olivier Latry, BSO & Gewandhausorchester â€“ Strauss: Festliches PrÃ¤ludium, Op. 61, TrV 229

The Symphony No. 9 in E minor, "From the New World", Op. 95, B. 178 (Czech: Symfonie Ä. 9 e moll â€Z novÃ©ho svÄ›taâ€œ), popularly known as the New World Symphony, was composed by AntonÃ­n DvoÅ™Ã¡k in 1893 while he was the director of the National Conservatory of Music of America from 1892 to 1895. It has been described as one of the most popular of all symphonies. In older literature and recordings, this symphony was â€“ as for its first publication â€“ numbered as Symphony No. 5. Astronaut Neil Armstrong took a tape recording of the New World Symphony along during the Apollo 11 mission, the first Moon landing, in 1969. The symphony was completed in the building that now houses the Bily Clocks Museum.

I. Adagio â€“ Allegro molto
The movement is written in sonata form and begins with an introductory leitmotif in Adagio. This melodic outline also appears in the third movement of DvoÅ™Ã¡k's String Quintet No. 3 in Eâ™­ major and his Humoresque No. 1. The exposition is based on three thematic subjects. The first in E minor is notable for its announcing and responsive phrases. The second is in G minor and undergoes a transformation such that it resembles a Czech polka. The exposition's closing theme in G major is known for being similar to the American negro spiritual "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot". The development primarily focuses on the main and closing themes, and the recapitulation consists of a repetition of the main theme as well as a transposition of the second and closing themes up a semitone. The movement is concluded with a coda, with the main theme stated by the brass above an orchestral tutti.

II. Largo
The second movement is introduced by a harmonic progression of chords in the wind instruments. Beckerman interprets these chords as a musical rendition of the narrative formula â€œOnce upon a timeâ€. The main theme is then played by the cor anglais (English horn) accompanied by muted strings. DvoÅ™Ã¡k was said to have changed the theme from clarinet to cor anglais as it reminded him of the voice of Harry Burleigh. The movement's middle section contains a passage in Câ™¯ minor evoking a nostalgic and desolate mood which eventually leads into a funeral march above pizzicato steps in the basses. It is followed by a quasi-scherzo that incorporates this movement's theme and first movement's main and closing themes. The Largo is concluded with soft return of the main theme and introductory chords.

III. Molto vivace
The movement is a scherzo written in ternary form, with influences from Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's The Song of Hiawatha. The stirring rhythm of the first part is interrupted by a trio middle section. The first part is then repeated, followed by an echo in the coda of the first movement's main theme.

IV. Allegro con fuoco
The final movement is also written in sonata form. After a brief introduction, the horns and trumpets declare the movement's main theme against sharp chords played by the rest of the orchestra. The second theme is then presented by the clarinet above tremolos in the strings. The development not only works with these two themes but also recalls the main themes of the first and second movements and a fragment of the Scherzo. Following the recapitulation which begins in the unexpected key of G minor but later corrects itself back to the original key, the movement reaches its climax in the coda, in which materials from the first three movements are reviewed for a final time while the Picardy third is expanded after the orchestra triumphantly plays a "modally altered" plagal cadence.

Title: Haydn: Symphony No. 94 â€œSurpriseâ€ | Andris Nelsons & the Lucerne Festival Orchestra
Description:
Wake up! It's the symphony â€œwith the kettledrum strokeâ€. Joseph Haydnâ€™s Symphony No. 94 in G major â€œSurpriseâ€ is probably his most famous symphony. Here, it is performed by the Lucerne Festival Orchestra under the direction of Andris Nelsons. The concert took place on 19 August 2015 at the Lucerne Culture and Congress Centre.

(00:00) I. Adagio cantabile â€“ Vivace assai
(08:55) II. Andante
(15:32) III. Menuetto: Allegro molto
(20:30) IV. Finale: Allegro molto

Joseph Haydn (1732 - 1809) composed the Symphony No. 94 in G major, Hob. I:94 â€œSurpriseâ€ in 1791 during his first visit to London. The premiere took place on March 23, 1792, in the Hanover Square Rooms and was an enormous success. Haydn himself conducted, leading the orchestra from the fortepiano.

The â€œSurprise Symphonyâ€ is the second of Haydnâ€™s twelve London Symphonies and a model of the classical four-movement symphony. Its nickname derives from the famous moment at the beginning of the second movement (09:31), when, after 15 measures of a gentle melody, a sudden fortissimo chord with timpani stroke bursts forth.

Legend has it that Haydn wanted to wake up dozing London concertgoers with this jolt. More likely, however, he had another aim in mind. As he told his biographer Georg August Griesinger: â€œI was interested in surprising the public with something new.â€ The English gave the work the nickname â€œSurprise,â€ which captures the effect of this fortissimo chord more vividly than the German title â€œSymphonie mit dem Paukenschlagâ€ (Symphony with the kettledrum stroke).

The shock in the second movement can easily overshadow the other qualities of the symphony, yet all four movements are masterfully crafted. The first movement, with its dance-like character, shifts gracefully between forte and piano and develops its two themes with elegance. The second movement delights with contrasting variations on a childlike tune. The third movement is deliberately simpleâ€”almost rusticâ€”reminiscent of an Alpine LÃ¤ndler. The finale recaptures the playfulness and drive of the opening movement and brings the work to a brilliant conclusion.

Born in Austria, Joseph Haydn played a decisive role in the history of the symphony. He wrote his first for Count Morzin of Bohemia, though he served him only briefly. In 1761 he became Kapellmeister to the EsterhÃ¡zy court in Hungary, where he composed numerous symphonies for its small orchestra. By the end of the 1760s Haydn had already written more than 40 symphonies, with another 25 following in the 1770s. By the 1780s he had reached full artistic maturity, and his works were performed throughout Europeâ€”and even, by 1782, in America.

In his final creative period, encompassing the twelve so-called London Symphonies, Haydnâ€™s mastery is most evident. He traveled to England for the first time in 1791 and enjoyed great success with his Symphonies Nos. 93â€“98. London boasted one of the finest orchestras of the day, offering Haydnâ€”long accustomed to the modest resources of the EsterhÃ¡zy courtâ€”new possibilities that deeply influenced his writing. He composed the second set of London Symphonies (Nos. 99â€“104) during his second visit (1794â€“95).

Even today, Symphony No. 94 conveys the poise, elegance, and spirit of invention that characterize Haydnâ€™s late style.

Title: Mahler: Symphony No. 5 | Andris Nelsons and the Lucerne Festival Orchestra
Description:
This can be regarded as a key work marking the transition from late Romantic music to so-called â€œNew Musicâ€: Gustav Mahlerâ€™s Symphony No. 5. The symphony written for an expanded orchestra is played by the Lucerne Festival Orchestra under the direction of Andris Nelsons. The concert took place on 19 August 2015 at the Lucerne Culture and Congress Centre.

Program:
(00:00) I. Trauermarsch. In gemessenem Schritt. Streng. Wie ein Kondukt (Funeral March. In measured pace. Strict. Like a cortÃ¨ge)
(14:10) II. StÃ¼rmisch bewegt. Mit grÃ¶ÃŸter Vehemenz (Stormily agitated. With the greatest vehemence)
(30:25) III. Scherzo. KrÃ¤ftig, nicht zu schnell (Scherzo. Vigorous, not too fast)
(48:39) IV. Adagietto. Sehr langsam (Adagietto. Very slow)
(59:50) V. Rondo-Finale. Allegro â€“ Allegro giocoso (Rondo-Finale. Allegro â€“ Allegro giocoso)

At the beginning of Gustav Mahlerâ€™s (1860â€“1911) Symphony No. 5 there is a nod to another famous classical work: the trumpetâ€™s opening motif, with its distinctive short-short-short-long rhythm, calls to mind the famous â€œfate motifâ€ of that most renowned Fifth Symphony of all â€”Ludwig van Beethovenâ€™s (1770â€“1827) Symphony No. 5 in C minor. The two works also share a parallel in their overall trajectory: Beethovenâ€™s begins with a dramatic, dark movement and ends with a triumphant march in the major key. Mahlerâ€™s Fifth likewise opens with a weighty funeral march that seems to pull everything downwards, while the finale arrives with playful, buoyant cheerfulness, culminating in such a dazzling close that it almost borders on parody. It is therefore quite possible that Mahler intended, in his own way, to carry Beethovenâ€™s great symphony forward.

After Beethoven, the symphony as a genre was regarded as a particular challenge. The standard set by the great classical master was one his successors felt compelled not only to match but to expand upon. Gustav Mahler achieved this in a unique manner. Formally, Mahlerâ€™s symphonic writing clearly draws upon Beethoven, yet departs from it in highly individual ways. His Symphony No. 5 illustrates this exemplary balance. Mahler drafted the first sketches in the summer of 1901, and by 1902 the long work was essentially completeâ€”apart from the orchestration, which occupied him intensely. An initial version was completed in 1903, with a revised one following in 1904. On October 18 of that year, the symphony premiered in Cologne with the composer conducting. Even in 1911, the year of his death, Mahler revisited the orchestration once more. This final version appeared in print as part of the collected edition of his works. Mahlerâ€™s mastery of orchestration was without peer in his time: not only did he expand the orchestra to monumental proportions, but he also deployed its instruments in strikingly unusual combinations. The result was a wealth of tonal colors that had never been heard previously.

Formally too, the Fifth Symphony is remarkable, for it encompasses two structural designs at once. On the one hand, it consists of five movements, the first functioning almost as a kind of prelude to the four-movement symphony that follows. On the other hand, the five movements are grouped into three large sections: movements 1 & 2, movement 3, and movements 4 & 5. At the center stands the third movement, a Scherzoâ€”an unprecedented focus on a Scherzo of unusual length. In this we see how Mahler, while rooted in traditional forms, simultaneously pushes beyond them.

Mahlerâ€™s style of motivic and thematic writing is particularly modern, already described in his day as a form of collage. In the Fifth Symphony too, themes and motifs sometimes clash in stark contrast, as though they had little to do with one another and were simply juxtaposed. Yet they are always woven together with profound compositional logic, exemplifying Mahlerâ€™s characteristic polyphonic technique. In this way, Mahler can be seen as a direct forerunner of New Music.

Fun fact: Today, Gustav Mahlerâ€™s Fifth ranks among his most beloved symphonies. The fourth movement, the Adagietto, played a special role in this. Luchino Visconti (1906â€“1976) used the movementâ€™s plaintive music in his film Death in Venice (Morte a Venezia, 1971), an adaptation of the novella by Thomas Mann (1875â€“1955). The main characterâ€”modeled in part on Gustav Mahler himselfâ€”is accompanied leitmotif-like throughout by the Adagietto.

Title: Prokofiev, Piano Concerto No. 3
Description:
Daniil Trifonov @daniiltrifonov 
Boston Symphony Orchestra @bostonsymphony / Andris Nelsons - 
Sergei Prokofiev: Piano Concerto No. 3 in C major, Op. 26  

Koussevitzky Music Shed, Lenox, MA, USA / July 7, 2023 
Opening Night at Tanglewood 

00:00 I. Andante - Allegro
10:16 II. Tema con variazioni 
19:52 III. Allegro, ma non troppo

30:56 Applause 

32:54 [Encore] Sergei Prokofiev - Three Pieces from "Cinderella", Op. 95: II. Gavotte 

36:38 Applause 

Steven Ledbetter, a musicologist and former Boston Symphony's program annotator, writes: 

Andris Nelsons, the BSO, and Daniil Trifonov sparked the wide-ranging 2023 Tanglewood season with high energy in a mostly Russian (plus Marsalis) program. [â€¦]

It begins with a wonderful lyricism (a quality that gradually came to dominate elements of Prokofievâ€™s later music, especially the ballets. But after this gentle beginning with woodwinds and a scurrying preparation in the strings, the soloist enters with dynamic fast music, often calling for pounding chords (for which the steely fingered Trifonov certainly showed the requisite muscularity), at some places hinting at Prokofievâ€™s frequent suggestions of Stravinsky, almost a decade his senior, whom Prokofiev often sought to outdo in rhythmic violence and dissonance (though never quite doing so), and suddenly reverting to gentle lyricism. Both pianist and orchestra gave full measure to both these expressive opposing forces.
For an encore, Trifonov stuck with Prokofiev but chose a delicate dance movement, a Gavotte, that the composer had transcribed from his ballet Cinderella. This was as crisp and clean and light as much of the concerto has been thunderous. [â€¦] 

https://www.classical-scene.com/2023/07/11/opens-tanglewood/ 


David M. Rice writes:

"[...] Daniil Trifonov exuded enthusiasm and eagerness to plunge into Prokofievâ€™s Third Piano Concerto, which he did most emphatically following William R. Hudginsâ€™s clarinet solo. Trifonov negotiated the Concertoâ€™s challenges with spectacular technique, capturing the musicâ€™s sarcastic wit and humor. After the piano echoed a clever juxtaposition of oboe, pizzicatos and castanets, Trifonov powerfully dashed off a series of rising and falling octaves to conclude the first movement. In the first of the middle movementâ€™s five variations, Trifonovâ€™s trills and glissando launched a lovely sentimental discourse, and in the more rapid-paced variation that followed, his traversal of intricate figurations, set against muted brass, was most impressive. The Finale featured fine playing from the woodwinds, beginning with the bassoons announcement of a humorous idea, and ending with a non-stop race that showed off Trifonovâ€™s incredible virtuosity. Trifonovâ€™s charming but staid encore, the Gavotte from Prokofievâ€™s Cinderella, seemed oddly anticlimactic. [...]" 

https://www.classicalsource.com/concert/boston-symphony-orchestra-andris-nelsons-conducts-opening-night-at-tanglewood-wynton-marsalis-tchaikovsky-and-prokofievs-third-piano-concerto-with-daniil-trifonov/ 


Edward Sava-Segal's review: 

There is little doubt that Daniil Trifonov, one the of the greatest pianists of his generation, was the primary reason why most people attended Friday nightâ€™s performance in the Koussevitzky Shed. He obliged with a performance of Prokofievâ€™s Piano Concerto no. 3 in C major that was not only technically immaculate but also respected the letter and the spirit of a score whose three movements are as much abrupt and stormy, as they are full of lyricism and memorable melodies. 

There was no sign of grandiloquence in a reading shaped with great intelligence and sensibility from the very first bars. Balances between ludic and gravitas, sarcastic and mysterious were outstandingly maintained in the central theme with variations. Trifonov and Nelsons allowed the details â€“ dissonant, poetic, even jazzy â€“ to resound in all their splendour in the last movement, the section where too many pianists ignore the ma non troppo indication to display their prowess at unfathomable speeds. There was a clear chemistry between pianist and orchestra. In one of those scores where the ensembleâ€™s contribution is as important as the soloistâ€™s, the latterâ€™s dialogues with different orchestral sections unfolded with verve and naturalness. Every piano intervention emerged organically from the orchestral tapestry.

A charming single encore, the Gavotte from Prokofievâ€™s Cinderella, was played in the same vein as the concertoâ€™s middle section, with wit subsumed by delicacy. 

https://bachtrack.com/review-trifonov-nelsons-prokofiev-marsalis-tchaikovsky-tanglewood-festival-july-2023

https://www.bostonglobe.com/2023/07/10/arts/bso-opens-its-85th-summer-tanglewood/

Title: Sebastian Currier: Aether (2018)
Description:
Sebastian Currier (*1959)
Aether, for violin and orchesta (2018)

Baiba Skride, violin
Gewandhausorchester Leipzig
Andris Nelsons, conductor


For much of the 18th and 19th centuries "aether" was thought to be an invisible substance that pervaded all of universe between celestial bodies. It was the medium through which light waves were thought to travel. The word itself looks back to Greek mythology. It means "pure, fresh air" and was thought to be the air of the upper atmosphere, the air the gods breathed. With Einsteinâ€™s theory of relativity the concept became outmoded, but it still lingers as a term referring to something remote, mysterious, invisible, and out of reach. Conceptually, Aether starts with a rather standard multimovement structure of a symphony or a concerto, but in the finished work this form is deconstructed and reconfigured. There are four primary movements. The first is a sort of nachtmusik where instruments from the orchestra play phrases that the violin imitates. In the second movement thereâ€™s a continual struggle between lyrical impulses and aggressive outbursts. The third movement is a sustained, lyrical slow movement where the violin soars above the orchestra. The fourth is an energetic, virtuosic finale. But thatâ€™s not actually how the piece unfolds. As the piece begins we hear very, very quiet, distant, mysterious chords in the strings, with the winds making ephemeral air sounds. Itâ€™s vague and atmospheric. Itâ€™s the medium which the four movements are contained; itâ€™s the "aether" that surrounds the firmer, more concrete structures of the four movements. It begins the piece, ends it, and occurs between all the four movements. The movements donâ€™t really conclude but just trail off into oblivion or, as in the fourth movement are interrupted unexpectedly. They float within this medium of aether. The violin is noticeably absent from these ethereal sections, except the last. Here the violin steps off the solid structure created by the four movements and floats into the aether, gradually disappearing into nothingness.


Photo by Robert Torres

Title: Unsuk Chin: Violin Concerto No. 2, â€Scherben der Stilleâ€œ (2021)
Description:
Unsuk Chin (*1961)
Violin Concerto No. 2, â€Scherben der Stilleâ€œ, for violin and orchestra (2021)

Leonidas Kavakos, violin
Boston Symphony Orchestra
Andris Nelsons, conductor

US PremiÃ¨re, 05 March 2022, Carnegie Hall

Co-commissioned by the London Symphony Orchestra, Boston Symphony Orchestra and Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, with the support of the Ernst von Siemens Music Foundation


With my Violin Concerto No. 2, titled Scherben der Stille (â€œShards of Silenceâ€), I decided to break my â€œprincipleâ€ of writing only one concerto for an instrument. Given that there is such a great history with symphonic repertoire, it is always a challenge for a contemporary composer to try to add something to a genre that is new and yet in a way that is idiomatic for the ingenious 19th-century invention, the symphony orchestra. Besides, I want to write for many other instruments, ensembles, and setups, and every new project requires ample research time. To provide a slightly far-fetched comparison, Glenn Gould once remarked that he only records a piece once but decided to make an exception with the Goldberg Variations, his first and last recording; both are entirely different, but equally brilliant, which is fascinating.

I decided to break with this â€œprincipleâ€ because of my encounter with Leonidas Kavakosâ€™s unique musicianship and artistic personality, which resulted in new ideas on tackling this genreâ€™s challenges. Therefore, this work is very different from my First Violin Concerto, which I composed twenty years ago. It also reflects the manifold new experiences I have had with this instrument since then, especially and most lately in Gran Cadenza, a violin duo commissioned by and written for Anne-Sophie Mutter. Nevertheless, it is very different from all the other music I have written for the violin, whether in soloistic function or as part of an ensemble.

My Violin Concerto No. 2 is a subjective portrait of and a dialogue with Leonidas Kavakosâ€™s musicianship, which is burningly intense, and at the same time, impeccable and completely focused.

It is cast in one movement: the solo violin part forms the foundation of the whole work; the soloist triggers all of the orchestraâ€™s actions and impulses. The work also features a composed solo cadenza that is very virtuosic.

The music is rich in contrast: the musical fabric emerges from utter silence butâ€”hence the title of the workâ€”juxtaposed seamlessly with rough edges, tonal shards and incisive outbursts from which new shapes appear.

A small motivic cell of five musical notes (or, to be more precise, two notes embellished by three natural harmonics) that soon turns into a line, a phrase, forms the creative nucleus of this piece, and it appears all over, in a variety of shapes and characters. The orchestra joins the soloist inconspicuously, starting from the almost imperceptible rustle of the beginning. Together with the soloistâ€™s actions, it results in delicate, iridescent soundscapes, the music being on the verge between emergence and decay. These minimal moves already catalyze many of the upcoming developments. But soon, the orchestra appears with more angular textures, and the motivic proto-cell turns into a manifold of shapes: occasionally resembling a delicate song, then morphing into ritual-like repetitive pulsations, and, towards the end of the piece into â€œbeatsâ€ that have a scream-like character. These changes sometimes happen with more fluent transitions and, more often, unexpected turns and even harsh contrasts.

Structurally speaking, Violin Concerto No. 2 consists of different sections that merge seamlessly: the grand form of the work resembles a labyrinth.
